website_summaries.verdict: This small electrical appliance replaces a traditional tortilla press and a heated grill, but the finished product still requires some further cooking. Ideal for food trucks and small commercial kitchens.
pros: No need for a separate press and grill
Creates a generous supply of raw tortillas as a cold press
cons: Not recommended for corn tortillas, only flour
Does not completely cook tortillas, just par-bakes

You do have to bake them afterwards, the heating element is warm enough to press the dough. They come out on the thicker side, but that's the way I like them.

customer_reviews.title: Magic tortilla press
customer_reviews.text: This tortilla press is great. You put a round little ball of dough towards the back, close it, and then 10 seconds later hold it down for 5 more seconds and in 15 seconds you have a perfectly round tortilla that is par-cooked. This does not completely cook the tortilla, it is made to cook it just enough so that it holds it's shape and then you store the stacks of tortillas in the fridge or freezer and cook them on a hot griddle for a couple of seconds before serving. This press pays for itself after about 15-20 batches of tortillas. Don't forget to store it with a thin layer of oil on the plates.

customer_reviews.title: Yum!
customer_reviews.text: Still waiting for mine, but my friend has one. It seems there is confusion about corn tortillas with this press. According to directions in the manual, for flour tortillas, use the press with the heat on (plugged in and let heat for 10 minutes before using), then cook in your pan or griddle. For corn tortillas, use it with no heat at all, just like a regular tortilla press, then cook in a pan/griddle like usual. We've had no problems at all

If you get a good recipe for flour tortillas, you'll never buy store tortillas again.
